text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with homemade flour tortillas if
you've never had homemade flour
tortillas you are in for a treat they
are nothing nothing like what you get in
the store there are thousand times
better they are also super super easy to
make in fact the only tricky part is
getting them rolled nice and thin but
we're not going to roll we're going to
use this a tortilla press I'm using this
Victoria model from me Musa which they
sent me to test a while back and it
worked fantastic so first we got to make
our tortilla dough so I'm going to
measure some flour into a bowl you'll
notice I'm using the scale more accurate
of course then cup measurements I'll
give you both I'm on food wishes but
we're going to use a certain weight of
white flour all-purpose flour some
baking powder some fine salt table salt
all right after the dry ingredients go
in I'm going to work a whisk through
that kind of to aerate it if there's any
chunks got to break them up you can also
sift it but I'm not a huge sifter
alright then we're going to throw in
some fat I'm using plain vegetable
shortening some people like to use lard
some people like to use butter some
people use a combination I'm going to
take my pastry cutter or pastry blender
which is that little wire thing and
simply work the fat into the flour until
it resembles coarse crumbs see that all
right well it looks like that stop I'm
going to make a well in the middle to
which I'm going to add hot water or very
warm water not boiling just hot water
okay I'm going to take a fork I'm going
to work that with the fork until it sort
of comes together I'm going to dump it
on my cutting board and I'm going to
knead it for about three minutes
to form a very smooth fairly soft dough
now this is not like a bread dough where
you have to knead it for like ten
minutes all right we don't need like a
really elastic dough so just a few
minutes usually takes care of it alright
so that dough should easily pick up all
the flour we used if it starts to stick
to the cutting board and all the flowers
been used up sprinkle a little more
flour on all right you got to play it by
ear when you make dough's
all right so the sticks add a little
more flour by the way I realized I was
needing
kind of fast so here's a little slow
motion of my kneading technique pretty
basic you kind of smoosh it with the
heel of your hand and then turn it over
and do it again
all right so I kept doing that like I
said three or four minutes until I had
something that looked and felt like that
at that point I'm going to put a little
more flour down on the board I'm going
to cover this with my bowl and let it
rest 15 to 20 minutes it's got to sort
of relax and what are you doing
while it's relaxing you relax all right
so 15 20 minutes later took off the bowl
you can use a knife I'm using one of
these dos scrapers so I cut it in half
cut the half in half cut the half half
in half translation cut them into eight
semi equal pieces you could weigh them
to make them all exactly the same but
that would just be you know annoying so
close is fine for tortillas all right
and then the only tricky part of the
operation rolling these nice and thin if
you have one of these you don't have to
do any rolling this is a standard basic
tortilla press you got to put some
plastic down so I like to give it a
little squirt of water which holds the
plastic in place so I'm going to put
plastic on the bottom plate another
piece on the top plate put my dough ball
in notice I have it sort of towards the
back hinge towards the back third that's
because it's going to press forward and
that tends to work a little easier and
then you just press the handle down so
easy all right once it's pressed we are
ready to cook and you can see how
beautifully uniform and flat that comes
and you can do the same thing by rolling
you can I've done it that way this is
just a lot easier and faster all right
over to a dry pan you can use a seasoned
cast iron you can use a nonstick like
I'm using here on medium-high heat
you're going to throw it in for about a
minute when you see bubbles popping up
like that give it a flip about a minute
on that side and you're going to see it
may and it probably will start to
inflate all right after about a minute
on that side I like to flip it over
again and then watch this is so cool so
it's about three minutes total
there's really no wrong way to do this
some people just go like a minute and a
half on each side I like to do two flips
so a minute flip a minute flip in a
minute flip and that is done tortilla
balloon by the way if you want to call
this flatbread call it flatbread really
the same thing all right that's it done
so cool so easy and dimension incredibly

over them to keep them warm if you have

anything to eat with them I just ate
employee
